idinfo.datacred:
This map layer was developed and is maintained by BCI personnel, from published literature and unpublished reports, with contributions from federal, State, and local agencies and private individuals. The contributors should receive most of the credit for the many days and nights in the field, and the many hours spent compiling records. Following is a list of the names of major publication authors and those who contributed significantly to the locality database. BCI thanks all contributors, but especially the following observers, collectors, curators, and authors:
R.A. Adams, H.T. Arita, D.M. Armstrong, R.H. Baker, R.W. Barbour, R.M.R. Barclay, T.L. Best, T.A. Bookhout, J.B. Bowles, P.V. Bradley, R.M. Brigham, M. Bunch, W. Caire, L.N. Caraway, L.R. Chandler-Mozisek, B.R. Chapman, S.S. Chapman, J.R. Choate, M.K. Clark, T.W. Clark, R.L. Clawson, B.C. Cochran, E.L. Cockrum, B. Coffin, D.G. Constantine, J.A. Cook, B.G. Crump, N. Czaplewski, W.W. Dahlquest, W.H. Davis, A.F. DiSalvo, M.E. Douglas, J.W. Dragoo, J.D. Druecker, P.B. Dunnigan, D.R. England, A.L. Everette, J.J.P. Farney, M.B. Fenton, C. Fichtel, J.S. Findley, E.D. Fleharty, P.A. Frank, J. Freeman, J.B. Funderburg, Jr., M.R. Gannon, D.L. Genter, B.P. Glass, F.B. Golley, F.F. Graves, Jr., D.R. Griffin, E.R. Hall, A.H. Harris, J.A. Hart, M.J. Hartley, M.J. Harvey, R.N. Hasenyager, E.B. Hazard, G.A. Heidt, P. Hendricks, M.J. Herder, H.B. Hitchcock, D.F. Hoffmeister, G.L. Holroyd, P. Horner, J.A. Howard, A.H. Howell, M.K. Hudson, S.R. Humphrey, H. Jackson, J.G. Jackson, W.L. Jennings, C. Jones, J.K. Jones, Jr., A. Keeley, B. Keeley, T. Keenan, R. Kellogg, M.L. Kennedy, G.L. Kirkland, W.M. Kiser, P.H. Krutzch, A. Kurta, M.J. Lacki, M.L. LaVal, R.K. LaVal, B.E. Lawhead, J.D. Lazell, Jr., D.S. Lee, C. Levesque, C.A. Long, G.H. Lowery, Jr., B. Luce, J.R. MacGregor, R.W. Manning, M.A. Mares, R. Maxey, V.R. McDaniel, K.P. McGuiness, L.M. Merk, H.G. Merriam, R.E. Mumford, B. Musgrove, D.W. Nagorsen, H.N. Neuhauser, D.I. Parker, H. Pawelczyk, J.M. Perkins, R.L. Peterson, Y. Petryszyn, L. Pfannmuller, E.D. Pierson, R.M. Pitts, M.A. Ports, J. Priday, W.R. Rainey, K.N. Randolph, D.W. Rice, M.C. Rowe, M.J. Sarell, D.A. Saugey, J.J. Scharninghausen, D.J. Schmidly, J.A. Sealander, R.G. Severson, M.S. Siders, H.C. Smith, D.W. Sparks, C. Stihler, M.R. Stromberg, J.M. Szewczak, J. Taylor, R. Tumlison, R.W. Turner, J. Tyburec, J.D. Tyler, C.A. Unger, C.G. van Zyll de Jong, R.L. Vaughn, B.J. Verts, J.O. Whitaker, Jr., D.E. Wilson, D.J. Worthington, F.D. Yancey, II.
The following natural heritage programs and museums also contributed records to the locality database:
Alabama Natural Heritage Program, Alaska Natural Heritage Program, Arkansas Natural Heritage Commission, Arizona Heritage Data Management System, Atlantic Canada Conservation Data Centre, California Department of Fish and Game, California Natural Database, Colorado Natural Heritage Program, District of Columbia Natural Heritage Program, Florida Natural Areas Inventory, Georgia Natural Heritage Program, Idaho Conservation Data Center, Illinois Natural Heritage Division, Indiana Natural Heritage Data Center, Kansas Natural Heritage Inventory, Louisiana Natural Heritage Program, Maine Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, Maine Natural Areas Program, Manitoba Department of Natural Resources, Manitoba Museum of Man and Nature, Massachusetts Natural Heritage and Endangered Species Program, Michigan Natural Features Inventory, Mississippi Natural Heritage Program, Missouri Natural Heritage Database, Montana Natural Heritage Program, Navajo Natural Heritage Program, Nevada Natural Heritage Program, New Hampshire Natural Heritage Inventory, New Jersey Natural Heritage Program, New Mexico Natural Heritage Program, New York Natural Heritage Program, North Carolina Natural Heritage Program, North Dakota Natural Heritage Inventory, Ohio Natural Heritage Data Base, Oklahoma Natural Heritage Inventory, Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument Bat Monitoring Database, Peabody Museum of Natural History, Pennsylvania Natural Diversity Inventory, Rhode Island Heritage Program, South Carolina Heritage Trust, South Dakota Natural Heritage Data
Base, Sternberg Museum of Natural History, Tennessee Division of Natural Heritage, Texas Biological and Conservation Data System, University of Nebraska State Museum, Vermont Nongame and Natural Heritage Program, Virginia Natural Heritage Program, Washington Natural Heritage Program, Washington Wildlife Heritage Database, West Virginia Nongame Wildlife and Natural Heritage Program, Wyoming Natural Diversity Database.

citeinfo.title: The Mammals of North America, Volumes I and II

attracc.attraccr:
Literature sources, museum experts, and other contributors were relied upon for identification of species.
Data are accurate to the best of originator's knowledge. Data compilation and checking were done manually; there is a possibility that some errors remain. Mexican data were collected to different standards, therefore the distributions shown for Mexico are not as accurate as for the U.S. or Canada.

dataqual.logic:
No tests for logical consistency were performed on these data.
The data used to create this file were collected over a 100-150 year period. No attempt has been made to separate historical from current distributions. A positive record does not necessarily imply current residence of the species. Records may represent either resident, migratory, or stray status. Not all areas have been surveyed or reported on as completely as others, so there remain gaps in the data used to compile the original occurrence file. As more fieldwork is completed and reported upon by researchers in these sparsely-known and sparsely-reported areas, future updates of this map layer should improve in these areas.
dataqual.complete: This map layer contains information on bat distribution for the 50 United States, the District of Columbia, and the 13 Canadian provinces and territories. No data were collected on bats of Puerto Rico or the U.S. Virgin Islands. Species distributions within Mexico are shown only for bats which also occur in the United States.

horizpa.horizpar: Due to the variety of sources used, there was varying accuracy in the way bat records were reported. Some of the reports were as latitude and longitude, UTM, or public land survey system coordinates. Some locations were given as a number of miles in a direction from a nearby town or landmark. Others were reported as just a mountain, park, or waterway. Each location was digitized to the nearest hundredth of a geographic degree as a single point based on the best description provided. If no specific location was reported more accurately than county level, the point was digitized to the center of the county, rounded to the nearest twentieth of a degree of longitude and latitude.

citeinfo.origin: Sources for these data are numerous. They include federal, State, local and university biologists; museums; heritage data centers; and published and unpublished reports.
citeinfo.title: Bat Location Source Data
citeinfo.othercit: The sources for these data are too numerous to list here. However, detailed information on each bat record is available from Bat Conservation International at the address listed in the contact information.

citeinfo.othercit: Due to the sensitivity of bat roosts to disturbance, actual locations of many of the data are considered confidential. BCI is unable to release actual locations to the public, so these files are not published in the usual sense of the word.

citeinfo.origin: Angela E. England, Bat Conservation International, Inc.
citeinfo.title: North American Bat Ranges

pubinfo.publish: National Atlas of the United States

procstep.procdesc:
Bat locality records were gathered from multiple sources, including U.S. natural heritage programs, Canadian conservation data centres, scientific literature publications, unpublished reports, museums, and information provided by university, federal, State, and local biologists. Records are all specimen, roost, capture, or positive visual identification-based; no acoustic-only identifications were used for this edition of the original occurrence files.
Each locality record was assigned longitude and latitude values to the nearest hundredth of a decimal degree. Records which were not already geocoded but which had place names were researched using the USGS Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) and the Canadian Geographic Names Data Base (CGNDB) 1997. Records located at various distances from place names were visually geocoded using the DeLorme Atlas and Gazetteer for the applicable State. Records which could not be geocoded with certainty were rounded to the nearest twentieth of a degree, as long as the resulting rounding kept the plotted position within the boundary of the originally reported county. Records only as specific as county-level were assigned a value corresponding to the center of the county according to the GNIS, rounded to the nearest twentieth of a degree.
Records were entered into MapInfo Professional version 6.5 GIS software. Fields for each record included species, State, county, geographic details, observations, longitude, latitude, date observed, source type, and source. Points were plotted and visually checked to ensure they plotted in the correct county. The resulting files were saved in the BatLoc database.

For each species, BatLoc was buffered with a 15-mile radius around each point locality, using the MapInfo software. The buffered data were overlaid on digital maps of Bailey's Ecoregions of the United States, Major Land Resource Area (MLRA) boundaries, the United States, Canada, and Mexico. Records near possible edges of each species distribution were scrutinized, and visually compared to MLRA and ecoregion boundaries. Previously published regional and species-authority maps were consulted, and bat working group and colleague input was compared. Records of single bats (non-colony, nonmultiple-captures) that were greater than 75 miles distant from most other points were not included in the main range polygon(s), and were indicated as separate points within the range files. Points were also used for records that were considered questionable by local experts. In certain regions where few data are available, as well as for species which are not well known or easily captured, colleague feedback was especially relied upon. The resulting maps were saved as BatRange.
The BatRange files were modified to match the National Atlas shorelines, and shapefiles were created.
Extraneous attributes were removed from bat014p020.dbf (Lasiurus cinereus - Hoary Bat) and bat044p020.dbf (Pipistrellus subflavus Eastern Pipistrelle).
